div.div:
standalone app
twitch IRC bot +
Ableton device manager

display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 732px; height: 1px; padding-top: 50px; margin-left: 55px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 130px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.p: A standalone application runs the IRC bot and manages the communications between users and the synth(s) loaded into Ableton Live.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 322px; height: 1px; padding-top: 840px; margin-left: 60px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 210px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.p: The sequencer is a MIDI effect that will send MIDI note on/off and duration messages to a MIDI instrument loaded in the same track.
The drum machine is a MIDI effect that sends note on/off messages or triggers samples.
The paramamapper is an audio effect, which allows it to be placed on any track type. This device allows commands (!f, !r, !mario, etc) to be mapped to parameters within the same Ableton track.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 322px; height: 1px; padding-top: 840px; margin-left: 415px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 210px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.p: The !t device controls the tempo for Ableton Live and may be placed only once per Live project. This is also a Max for Live audio effect so that it may be placed on any track.
All devices receive data and report to the standalone app using the OSC protocol via UDP ports 8008 and 9009.
The devices are exported as Live devices from the Max project. This allows for all dependencies to be packaged with the devices themselves.

switch.text: The !t device controls the tempo for Ableton Live and...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 292px; height: 1px; padding-top: 170px; margin-left: 495px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 220px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.p: The standalone app is the brains that control the various body parts of the application. It is a Max project that contains a [node.script] object that communicates between the Twitch IRC channel and the Ableton Live devices.

The node.js script receives the commands from the other Twitch users, parses them, then outputs the parsed commands in the form of Max lists. Each list is then broadcast to all the Live devices via OSC. The devices filter out unwanted commands, then act on commands intended for them.

a.text: Viewer does not support full SVG 1.1
